description: From Middle English smerten, from Old English smeortan (“to smart”), from Proto-Germanic *smertaną (“to hurt, ache”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)merd- (“to bite, sting”). Cognate with Scots smert, Dutch smarten, German schmerzen, Danish smerte, Swedish smärta.

verbs.description: smart (third-person singular simple present smarts, present participle smarting, simple past smarted or (obsolete) smort, past participle smarted or (obsolete) smorten)

examples: After being hit with a pitch, the batter exclaimed "Ouch, my arm smarts!"

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause a smart or sting in.
examples: A goad that  […]  smarts the flesh.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To feel a pungent pain of mind; to feel sharp pain or grief; be punished severely; to feel the sting of evil.
examples: He that is surety for a stranger shall smart for it.

description: From Middle English smert, smart, from Old English smeart (“smarting, smart, painful”), from Proto-Germanic *smartaz (“hurting, aching”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)merd- (“to bite, sting”). Cognate with Scots smert (“painful, smart”), Old Frisian smert (“sharp, painful”).

adjectives.description: smart (comparative smarter or more smart, superlative smartest or most smart)

examples: Synonyms: bright, capable, sophisticated, witty
Antonyms: backward, banal, boorish, dull, inept

entries.meaning: (informal) Exhibiting intellectual knowledge, such as that found in books.
examples: Synonyms: cultivated, educated, learned; see also Thesaurus:learned
Antonyms: ignorant, uncultivated, simple

entries.meaning: (often in combination) Equipped with intelligent behaviour (digital/computer technology).
examples: smart car
smartcard
smartphone
Synonyms: attractive, chic, dapper, stylish, handsome
Antonyms: garish, outré, tacky
a smart outfit
You look smart in that business suit.

entries.meaning: Cleverly shrewd and humorous in a way that may be rude and disrespectful.
examples: Synonym: silly
He became tired of his daughter's sarcasm and smart remarks.
Don't get smart with me!

There is a smart shower at 5 P.M., and in the midst of it a hummingbird is busy about the flowers in the garden, unmindful of it, though you would think that each big drop that struck him would be a serious accident.
a smart pain

entries.meaning: (Southern US, dated) Intense in feeling; painful. Used usually with the adverb intensifier right.
examples: He raised his voice, and it hurt her feelings right smart.
That cast on his leg chaffs him right smart.
a smart gown
a smart breeze

description: From Middle English smerte, from smerten (“to smart”); see above. Cognate with Scots smert, Dutch smart, Low German smart, German Schmerz, Danish smerte, Swedish smärta. More above.

entries.meaning: A sharp, quick, lively pain; a sting.
examples: The smart of his wounded hand woke Scobie at two in the morning.

entries.meaning: Mental pain or suffering; grief; affliction.
(slang, dated) A dandy; one who is smart in dress; one who is brisk, vivacious, or clever.
